results.title: The Twilight zone: Rod Serling's lost classics
results.creator_credit: Robert Markowitz, S. Bryan Hickox and O'Hara-Horowitz Productions
results.brief_description: James Earl Jones presents two previously unscreened “Twilight zone” episodes written by Rod Serling and made for television in 1994. “The Theatre”: Commitment shy theatre technician Melissa goes alone to view Cary Grant’s “His girl Friday” at the cinema, only to witnesses scenes from her life earlier in the day appearing before her, but no-one else can see what she sees. Leaving the theatre to speak to her partner whom she believes has set up the stunt, she returns to the movie theatre having spoken to him who declined the claim, only to find the last 30 minutes of her life projected on the screen also, some of which present alarming future scenarios. Cast includes Amy Irving and Gary Cole. “Where the dead are”: Boston 1868, Civil War surgeon Dr Ramsay treats a charity case brought in but the man dies on the operating table. Investigating further, Ramsay discovers a scar indicating a skull fracture that should have taken the man’s life years ago. Ramsay’s obsession with death and belief that life is tantamount is piqued by the case and he travels to a mysterious island where he meets retired apothecary Dr Jeremy Wheaton who has conducted experiments in tissue regeneration as well as treating Ramsay’s mystery patient. Cast includes Patrick Bergin and Jack Palance.

results.title: The Twelve tasks of Asterix
results.creator_credit: Albert Uderzo, Goscinny, Pierre Watrin, Georges Dargaud, Dargaud Films and Idefix Studios
results.brief_description: In 50 BC Gaul is a quiet, peaceful place. Ceasar has recently subjected the country to a Roman invasion and renamed the place, France. Only a small pocket of Gauls remain; eponymous warrior Asterix, best friend Obelix and his canine companion Dogmatix, village chief, respected druid and creator of Asterix’s magic potion, Vitalstatistix, as well as Getafix and Cacofonix. When an army of Julius Ceasar’s guards attack the Gauls, they cannot believe the strength of their opponents and return to Caesar claiming they have come up against a group of gods. Caesar is not convinced however, and, inspired by the 12 deeds of Hercules, sets the Gauls 12 new tasks to prove their godliness and earn their freedom from Roman occupation, perhaps even take up a leadership position. The tasks include: footrace, the javelin, gladiator, Isle of Pleasure, the Eyes of Isis, eat it all, cave of the beast, form 838, the invisible high wire, answer the riddle, plain of the invisible spirits and the final task.

results.title: The Turn of the screw
results.creator_credit: Petr Weigl, Hans-Gunther Herbetz, Zdenek Oves, Fernseh produktiongesellschaft and Unitel
results.brief_description: This is an opera based on the Henry James story “Turn of the screw” written by Benjamin Britten. Performed by the Royal Opera at Covent Garden, it features Magdalena Vasaryova, Juraj Kukura and Dana Medricka. The story revolves around a governess who looks after two orphaned children in the country on the proviso that she would never write to their young guardian, their uncle.

results.title: The Truth about cats and dogs
results.creator_credit: Michael Lehmann, Cari-Esta Albert, Richard Hashimoto, Noon Attack and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: When panicked photographer Brian has trouble with a disagreeable Great Dane, he calls Dr Abby Barnes (Janeane Garofalo) a radio veterinarian whose daily program helps people with their problem pets. The pair develop an instant connection over the telephone and the eager Brian invites Abby out, asking for a description of herself so he can find her in a crowd. Lacking in self-confidence, Abby describes her neigbour, best friend and model, Noelle (Uma Thurman). When Abby stands him up, Ben comes to the studio looking for answers, and happens to see Noelle. Abby explains the situation to Noelle, who agrees to take her place, while Abby assumes the character of Donna. While Abby develops a relationship with Brian over the telephone and the radio, Noelle is the woman he believes he is talking to. Things become more complicated when Noelle falls for Brian, and Brian starts to wonder why his new girlfriend seems to have two different personalities.

results.title: The Two Gentlemen of Verona
results.creator_credit: Don Taylor, Shaun Sutton and BBC
results.brief_description: Porteous betrays his love, Julia, and deceives his close friend Valentine when the two become rivals for the affections of Silvia, who flees to the forest in protest. Valentine becomes an outlaw pursued by Proteous and his page (Julia in disguise). Valentine eventually forgives his treacherous friend and marries Silvia while Proteous marries Julia.

results.title: The Two-wheeled time machine
results.creator_credit: David Lowe, Miriam Stein and AFTRS
results.brief_description: An Australian fairy-tale where Henry Howard in his adolescence discovers how to travel through time. After failing to convince his childhood sweetheart to travel with him he sets off on his adventure. The film follows Alice’s life as she grows up into adulthood and beyond. She is visited by the increasingly sad Henry who discovers his travels are meaningless without her. Starring Matt Day, Essie Davis and Jacki Weaver.

results.title: The Twilight zone. Volume 2
results.brief_description: This video contains four episodes from the popular television series, “The Twilight Zone”. Included on this tape are; “Time enough at last” (originally broadcast in 1959), bookworm Henry Berris (Burgess Meredith) is thwarted in his attempts at reading. After a bomb hits it seems his problems are over and he has the peace and quiet he requires; only there’s one ironic catch. “After hours” (originally broadcast in 1960), when Anne Francis finds herself locked in a department store overnight she unravles the mystery of the ninth floor, but not by choice. “The Changing of the guard” (originally screened in 1962), Donald Pleasence plays a disgruntled but saintly school teacher, recently retrenched, who vows to return to his old school room and commit suicide. A surprise awaits him that will change his destiny. “Monsters due on Maple Street” (originally screened in 1960), things are looking grim on Maple Street. The power is out, cars won’t start and the phones are dead. The indications are that monsters ahev invaded the earth, only where are they? Cast includes Claude Akins and John Weston.

results.title: The Twilight zone. Volume 1
results.brief_description: This video contains four episodes of the long-running classic television series. “The Invaders” (screened originally in January 1962) stars Agnes Moorehead as an impoverished woman who is stalked by tiny spacemen in her small cabin. “One for the Angels” (screened originally in October 1959) has Mr. Death coming for salesman Ed Wynn - but before he departs the Earth he will makes his greatest pitch - to the Angels. In “The Eye of the beholder” (screened originally in November 1960) the bandages are removed from a facially deformed woman only to reveal a more hideous nightmare. In “The Lonely” (screened originally in November 1959), on a deserted planet convicted criminal Jack Warden must serve his long sentence alone - until his jailers take pity and leave him a beautiful robot woman. Can a man’s desperation lead to love?

results.title: The Twilight forest
results.creator_credit: Sydney Latter, James Mellor and Editorial Film Productions
results.brief_description: For centuries the African has made his home in the tropical rain forests of Nigeria and Ghana, surrounded by giant trees - walnut, mahogan y, agba, iroko and many others - whose wealth lay wasted. This film tells the dramatic story of an industrial enterprise which showed for the first time how these resources could be used.

results.title: The Turn of the screw
results.creator_credit: Dan Curtis and Dan Curtis Productions
results.brief_description: Based on Henry James’ novel “The Turn of the screw,” this made for television adaptation stars Lynn Redgrave as Miss Jane Cubberly, a young English governess who is hired to take care of two orphaned children, Miles (Jasper Jacob) and Flora (Eva Griffith), who live in an old country mansion. However, it is not long before Miss Cubberly soon discovers that things are not quite as they seem. The children’s behaviour is most disturbing and at times bordering on evil, whilst the house itself appears to possess an unnatural “presence.” This gothic horror has been adapted into many film versions, most notably “The Innocents” in 1961 starring Deborah Kerr and directed by Jack Clayton. Cast also includes: Megs Jenkins, John Baron, Anthony Lagdon, Kathryn Scott, James Laurenson, Benedict Taylor.
